raw_text:
Looks and music to drive mobiles
 
 Mobile phones are still enjoying a boom time in sales, according to research from technology analysts Gartner.
 
 More than 674 million mobiles were sold last year globally, said the report, the highest total sold to date. The figure was 30% more than in 2003 and surpassed even the most optimistic predictions, Gartner said. Good design and the look of a mobile, as well as new services such as music downloads, could go some way to pushing up sales in 2005, said analysts. Although people were still looking for better replacement phones, there was evidence, according to Gartner, that some markets were seeing a slow-down in replacement sales.
 
 "All the markets grew apart from Japan which shows that replacement sales are continuing in western Europe," mobile analyst Carolina Milanesi told the BBC News website. "Japan is where north America and western European markets can be in a couple of years' time. "They already have TV, music, ringtones, cameras, and all that we can think of on mobiles, so people have stopped buying replacement phones."
 
 But there could be a slight slowdown in sales in European and US markets too, according to Gartner, as people wait to see what comes next in mobile technology. This means mobile companies have to think carefully about what they are offering in new models so that people see a compelling reason to upgrade, said Gartner. Third generation mobiles (3G) with the ability to handle large amounts of data transfer, like video, could drive people into upgrading their phones, but Ms Milanesi said it was difficult to say how quickly that would happen. "At the end of the day, people have cameras and colour screens on mobiles and for the majority of people out there who don't really care about technology the speed of data to a phone is not critical." Nor would the rush to produce two or three megapixel camera phones be a reason for mobile owners to upgrade on its own. The majority of camera phone models are not at the stage where they can compete with digital cameras which also have flashes and zooms.
 
 More likely to drive sales in 2005 would be the attention to design and aesthetics, as well as music services. The Motorola Razr V3 phone was typical of the attention to design that would be more commonplace in 2005, she added. This was not a "women's thing", she said, but a desire from men and women to have a gadget that is a form of self-expression too. It was not just about how the phone functioned, but about what it said about its owner. "Western Europe has always been a market which is quite attentive to design," said Ms Milanesi.
 
 "People are after something that is nice-looking, and together with that, there is the entertainment side. "This year music will have a part to play in this." The market for full-track music downloads was worth just $20 million (£10.5 million) in 2004, but is set to be worth $1.8 billion (£9.4 million) by 2009, according to Jupiter Research. Sony Ericsson just released its Walkman branded mobile phone, the W800, which combines a digital music player with up to 30 hours' battery life, and a two megapixel camera. In July last year, Motorola and Apple announced a version of iTunes online music downloading service would be released which would be compatible with Motorola mobile phones. Apple said the new iTunes music player would become Motorola's standard music application for its music phones. But the challenge will be balancing storage capacity with battery life if mobile music hopes to compete with digital music players like the iPod. Ms Milanesi said more models would likely be released in the coming year with hard drives. But they would be more likely to compete with the smaller capacity music players that have around four gigabyte storage capacity, which would not put too much strain on battery life.
llama3.2:1b:
Mobile phones sold 674 million last year globally, up 30% from 2003 and exceeding predictions. Design and new services such as music downloads could drive sales in 2005.

Replacement sales continued in Japan and western European markets but slowed in US and European markets due to waiting for next-generation mobile technology.

New third generation mobiles (3G) with data handling capabilities may stimulate upgrades, but the process will be slow.

Design aesthetics and music services are more likely to drive sales than camera phone features. Western Europe is particularly attentive to design, with a market that values nice-looking phones alongside entertainment options.
llama3.2:3b: Mobile phone sales reached 674 million globally last year, surpassing previous predictions. Design and aesthetics, as well as new services like music downloads, drove sales. Some markets saw a slowdown in replacement sales, with people looking for better phones before upgrading. The rise of 3G mobiles could drive upgrades, but the focus on design and entertainment is likely to remain more important. Music downloads are expected to grow, with the market projected to reach $1.8 billion by 2009.
gemma2:2b: Smartphone sales are booming, with over 674 million units sold in 2004.  Design and aesthetics, along with new music services like downloads, will be key drivers of sales growth.  While replacement phone sales have slowed in some markets (such as Japan), demand for newer models will likely come from features such as 3G capabilities.  Music download services are anticipated to grow significantly, but challenges remain regarding balancing capacity with battery life.
qwen2.5:0.5b:
Mobile phones are enjoying a boom time globally thanks to continued growth and new services like music downloads. Key points include:

- More than 674 million mobiles sold last year.
- The highest total sold to date in history.
- Good design, the look of a mobile, and new services could drive sales in 2005.
- Japan is seeing a slowdown in replacement sales.
- Gartner predicts more attention to design aesthetics and music will drive sales in 2005.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Gartner forecasts mobile phone sales will continue growing in 2005 due to improved design and music services. Third-generation phones drive upgrades but may take longer for camera phones. Design and aesthetics are expected to be more crucial factors leading up to a 2005 slowdown, with the focus on entertainment following next.
qwen2.5:3b: Mobile phones are experiencing a sales boom, with 674 million units sold last year globally, surpassing even optimistic projections. Analysts attribute this success partly to good design and new services like music downloads, particularly in the European and US markets. Gartner predicts a potential slowdown due to cautious upgrades driven by new mobile technology such as third-generation (3G) phones capable of handling large data transfers. However, attention to design and aesthetics, along with music services, are more likely to drive sales in 2005. Sony Ericsson's Walkman-branded phone offers digital music players combined with cameras, while Apple's iTunes service for Motorola phones suggests increasing integration of multimedia features into mobile devices. The market for full-track music downloads is projected to grow from $20 million in 2004 to $1.8 billion by 2009, though storage capacity must be balanced against battery life.
opencoder:1.5b: The summary of the text provided reveals key trends and insights from a perspective of technology and consumer behavior. It summarizes how the mobile phone industry has evolved over the years, from a focus on high-speed internet to more compact models and a more focused on music downloads.
smollm:1.7b:
The summary is concise and objective, preserving key ideas and details from the original text. The main points covered are:

1. Looks and music to drive mobiles - This is a key driver of sales in 2005, as people look for better replacement phones and want new features like music downloads.
2. Good design and the look of a mobile - People also value the look of a mobile phone, including its design, camera, and other features.
3. New services to drive sales - The introduction of new services like music downloading, video streaming, and high-speed internet access is expected to drive sales in 2005.
4. Japan's market growth - Japan was the only market that saw a significant increase in mobile phone sales last year, with more than 674 million mobiles sold.
5. Good design and aesthetics - The attention to design and aesthetics of new mobile phones is expected to be important in 2005.
6. Music as a key feature - Music will play an increasingly important role in the mobile phone market in 2005, with more models offering full-track music downloading capabilities.
7. Apple's iTunes integration - Apple has announced that its new iTunes music player will be compatible with Motorola mobile phones, which could help to increase sales of music on mobile devices.
8. Challenges for mobile phone manufacturers - The introduction of new services and the increasing importance of design and aesthetics are expected to challenge mobile phone manufacturers to innovate and differentiate their products in 2005.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, I need to summarize the given text concisely by preserving key ideas and details. Let me read through it first.

The text talks about mobile phones' success in 2005 with a focus on design, music features, and new services. It mentions the report from Gartner showing significant growth and some issues like slow replacement sales in certain markets. There are specific examples of models like Razr V3 by Motorola and the Walkman brand from Sony Ericsson.

So I should highlight that mobile phones saw strong growth with attention to design and music, especially full-track downloads in 2005. Also, note that there were some market challenges, especially for cameras and storage capacity.

I'll structure the summary to include the main points: strong sales growth, key features (design, music services), examples of models, and any limitations or issues mentioned.
</think>

The mobile phones experienced significant growth in 2005 with a focus on design and music services. Key highlights included full-track music downloads, especially in 2004, which were worth $20 million. Models like the Razr V3 by Motorola and the Sony Ericsson Walkman brand were notable. However, there were challenges with cameras and storage capacity affecting sales.
tinyllama:1.1b: The technology analysts Garner Research have reported that more mobile phone sales are expected in 2005 than in any year since the boom time of 2003, with 674 million sold globally. The figure is 30% more than the previous record, and surpassed even by the most optimistic predictions, according to analysts Garner. While consumers still want new replacement mobile phones due to their high prices, some market segments are likely to see a slowdown in sales. Mobile companies have to think carefully about what they offer in new models to retain customers and attract people who may be waiting for better replacement phones. Third-generation (3G) mobile technology with the ability to handle large amounts of data transfer is driving sales, but consumers still prefer stylish designs with flashy cameras over high-speed data transfers. As a result, most camera phone models are not at the stage where they can compete with digital camera models that also have flashes and zoom lenses. However, design and aesthetics will continue to drive sales in 2005.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The summary of the text says: The global mobile phone market is predicted to hit a new record high in sales, as more than 674 million phones were sold in 2005. Gartner predicts that this growth will be driven by improvements in design and music download services. In addition to improved designs, the focus on attractive, affordable products is expected to drive sales in 2005. Analysts recommend focusing on the key features of these products before introducing them into the market.
phi:2.7b: According to Gartner research, global mobile phone sales reached 674 million in 2004, a 30% increase from 2003 and higher than the most optimistic predictions. The report noted that good design and new services like music downloads are driving sales in 2005. However, some markets may experience a slowdown in replacement phone sales due to the saturation of technology features. Mobile companies must offer compelling reasons for people to upgrade their phones, such as 3G technology or better camera features. Design and aesthetics are also important factors that will likely drive mobile phone sales in 2005. The market for full-track music downloads is worth $1.8 billion by 2009 and Sony Ericsson has released a music-focused phone with two megapixel camera and up to 30 hours' battery life. More models will likely be released with storage capacity, but this must balance with battery life concerns.
orca-mini:3b: Sales of mobile phones are still high and increasing, according to Gartner analysts. More than 674 million mobiles were sold in 2004, the highest total ever, with growth continuing in some markets. Design, aesthetics, and music services could drive sales in 2005, but competition from digital cameras, as well as battery life concerns, may limit their impact.
hermes3:3b: Mobile phone sales soar; design, look (e.g. Motorola Razr V3 aesthetics), and music downloads may drive demand in 2005.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Gartner reports over 674 million mobile phone sales in 2004, a 30% increase from 2003 and surpassing predictions. Good design, including aesthetics, and new services like music downloads could contribute to increased sales in 2005. Analysts note that markets like Japan demonstrate a slowdown in replacement sales, while the European and US markets may also experience slight slowdowns. Attention to design and music services are more likely drivers of sales in 2005. The market for full-track music downloads is projected to grow from $20 million in 2004 to $1.8 billion by 2009.
stablelm2:1.6b:
Mobile phone sales hit a record high of over 10 million units worldwide last year, according to Gartner. The report suggests growth in markets such as Western Europe and North America, while Japan sees slow replacement sales. Design and aesthetics, music services, and improvements in storage capacity remain key factors driving mobiles sales. Services like music downloads are expected to grow significantly over the next few years, with Jupiter Research predicting full-track music download market value at $1.8 billion by 2009. Companies such..
as Motorola and Apple are releasing digital music player phones that will be compatible with iTunes. These models would likely have hard drives, which would compete with smaller-capacity music players that don't strain the battery life.
granite3.1-dense:2b:
In 2004, over 674 million mobile phones were sold worldwide, marking a 30% increase from 2003 and surpassing previous predictions. This growth was attributed to better design and new services like music downloads. While replacement sales remained strong in western Europe, some markets showed signs of slowing down as people wait for advancements in mobile technology. Third-generation (3G) capabilities and improved data transfer could drive future upgrades, but the need for faster data speeds is less critical due to existing features like cameras and color screens.

In 2005, attention to design and aesthetics, along with music services, was expected to significantly impact sales. Design-focused phones, such as Motorola's Razr V3, appeal not only to functionality but also to self-expression. The full-track music download market is projected to grow from $20 million in 2004 to $1.8 billion by 2009, according to Jupiter Research. Sony Ericsson's Walkman-branded W800 and Motorola's iTunes compatibility demonstrate this trend, offering digital music players with long battery life and up to 30 hours' usage time.

Balancing storage capacity with battery life remains a challenge for mobile music competitors aiming to rival devices like the iPod. To address this, more phones with hard drives are likely to be released in the coming year, targeting smaller-capacity music players that would not excessively drain batteries.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Global mobile phone sales reached a record 674 million units in 2004, a 30% increase from 2003, according to Gartner. While replacement sales continued in Western Europe, Japan saw a slowdown as its market was already saturated with advanced features like TV, music, and cameras. A similar slowdown is expected in Europe and the US as consumers wait for new innovations. Third-generation (3G) technology could drive upgrades, but its impact remains uncertain. Instead, design and aesthetics, along with music services, are expected to boost sales in 2005. Phones like the Motorola Razr V3 highlight the growing demand for stylish devices as a form of self-expression. Music services are also gaining traction, with the mobile music market projected to grow from $20 million in 2004 to $1.8 billion by 2009. Sony Ericsson's Walkman phone and Motorola's collaboration with Apple on iTunes-compatible phones signal a shift towards integrating digital music players into mobiles. However, balancing storage capacity with battery life remains a challenge for mobile music to compete with standalone digital music players.
reference: Apple said the new iTunes music player would become Motorola's standard music application for its music phones.Third generation mobiles (3G) with the ability to handle large amounts of data transfer, like video, could drive people into upgrading their phones, but Ms Milanesi said it was difficult to say how quickly that would happen.Good design and the look of a mobile, as well as new services such as music downloads, could go some way to pushing up sales in 2005, said analysts.In July last year, Motorola and Apple announced a version of iTunes online music downloading service would be released which would be compatible with Motorola mobile phones.But the challenge will be balancing storage capacity with battery life if mobile music hopes to compete with digital music players like the iPod.Sony Ericsson just released its Walkman branded mobile phone, the W800, which combines a digital music player with up to 30 hours' battery life, and a two megapixel camera.This means mobile companies have to think carefully about what they are offering in new models so that people see a compelling reason to upgrade, said Gartner.It was not just about how the phone functioned, but about what it said about its owner.But there could be a slight slowdown in sales in European and US markets too, according to Gartner, as people wait to see what comes next in mobile technology.Nor would the rush to produce two or three megapixel camera phones be a reason for mobile owners to upgrade on its own.Ms Milanesi said more models would likely be released in the coming year with hard drives.More likely to drive sales in 2005 would be the attention to design and aesthetics, as well as music services.
